Are you aware that the Great Depression did not end until the government started spending massively to fight WWII?

If Obama can be blamed for anything, it is that he did not spend enough (his stimulus was way too weak and now Republicans want to cut government spending).

Republicans should heed that old maxim: those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. In 1936 FDR assumed the Great Depression was over because he had reduced unemployment from 25% to about 14% with his New Deal legislation (putting people to work). He then stupidly bought into Republican supply-side economics and cut spending to balance the budget (just what Republicans are preaching today). The result was that the country lurched back into recession that only ended when the government resumed spending to fight WWII. Thus proving Keynes correct and Republican supply-side economics to be bunk.

On Saturday, my husband and I arrived at our local organic supermarket in Westchester County, located in Mount Kisco, the town in which, coincidentally, Gov. Cuomo owns a home, to find several employees whom we'd known for many years, standing outside with leaflets and a union organizer. They'd been fired, according to the union for contacting public officials about working conditions at the store.

We then learned that, a few months ago, the NLRB set aside an election that the union had lost, after the union had filed complaints alleging worker intimidation.

We are, of course, supporting the workers, including by contacting the governor and our local representatives. I was thinking, however, while writing those letters and preparing to make those phone calls - I will do that tomorrow - how so much of income inequality has been facilitated by the decline of labor unions. People who denigrate unions don't realize that it was unions that protected and helped grow the middle class. Individuals don't have the power to fight the one percent. Politicians are too often merely tools of wealthy interests. It was - and is - the labor movement that spoke for the rest of us.

My family will support the workers at the organic supermarket by taking our business elsewhere until the workers rehired, and fair election is held. Many of our neighbors have said they will join us. I only wish that more Americans would understand that supporting labor is the best way of benefiting us all.

I like this double use of the word TIME here, but, for some reason, it took me a minute to figure out the word SHARE here. Once I got it, I liked the revealer better, and I particularly like the naturalness of the theme entries, with no hint of their relationship with the theme aside from the italic clues.

Aside from the theme entries, I liked: I DUNNO, HOLD 'EM, MAGNETO, and BLEND IN.

For clues, I liked: ["Oops-a-daisy"], [Brian who composed "Music for Airports"], the cross-ref clues for the intersecting TRIED and TRUE.

Missed opportunity for a clue today: 16A ALLEN should have been [Seattle Seahawks owner Paul]. If my theme isn't obvious today, it should be obvious by tomorrow. (With ~78 words a day, I'm gambling that I can come up with a clue every day this week. Wish me luck.)

BTW, Deb notes that FIBONACCI is a debut word today. That's true only in the literal sense. Jonah Kagan had a puzzle May 11, 2011 that was based on the Fibonacci sequence and had FIBONACCI SERIES as a theme entry. It's a cute puzzle. Charles Barasch also used FIBONACCI SERIES in 2007. And it was only two weeks ago that Lynn Lempel clued SERIES as [1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, 34 ..., e.g.]. While the proper term is Fibonacci Sequence, a sequence is also a series (though not vice versa).

One needs to ask how "teaching the test" became the method du jour.

Any liberal...er...progressive with the intellectual honesty willing to give a varnish-free assessment of the last 40-years of "liberalism" in our education system?

That might well be a good start at addressing the problem.

I am always amused how the NYTimes editors never bother to read their own paper. First Michael Winerip wrote several articles on why VAM was an unfair indicator for judging good teaching. That same day the editors wrote why using test scores should be kept in place. He also wrote how PAR was a better system-a system that didn't rely on test scores yet helped teachers improve or leave the system. The editors ignored that piece and praised the use of test scores for teacher evals. He also wrote how Tennessee's evaluations were seriously flawed, yet the editors wrote a commentary claiming Tennessee should not halt the evaluation system despite its flaws. (Soon after, Winerip was removed from reporting on Education.)

Yesterday the Times had an article about a special program that helps disadvantage students get better grades through both tutoring and counseling. Yet, this paper ignores the many factors that go into a test score. Under Bloomberg, good schools received B report cards. VAM was unable to measure improvement because these schools were already successful.
The editors are so intent on continuing a path that not only hinders students, but public education as well.
Thankfully deBlasio has seen how schools that were improving and had the support of the community were closed under the Bloomberg regime due to an unfair reporting system.

It's time to stop teaching to the test and instead start teaching to the child.

An overlooked fact in the old school/new school debate is the access to audience and growth. Try as I might, I can't find the old newsstands and stores that offered the Times, Post, Tribute, Journal-Constitution in print form. Millions of interested readers lack outside of metropolitan areas want first class insight, timely stories, and reporting on events and trends beyond their locale. Only the web offers this very real advantage, and can augment it with video,sound, and images that fill out content in a way that most news sites can not.

I don't disagree with you on the need to let kids who want to shunt off towards the technical trades rather than the academic track. We need this and we need it badly.

Where I disagree is having New York do it on its own. In my opinion, this needs to be done on a national level and not piecemeal. We need to make sure we have the infrastructure to move in that direction with technical high schools being established and community colleges that are ready to receive technical students who want to further their technical skills. We also need to have industries on-board with this, collaborating and providing apprenticeships and career tracks that will ensure these graduates' careers in the long term.

Frankly, given today's complete lack of interest in investing in the long term by politicians of a certain bent and big business in general, I don't see this happening for decades.

But we need it. Badly.

Ms. Regas...Since the Constitution of the United States limits the scope of the federal government to only those powers specifically enumerated, what you wish would be utterly unconstitutional since "education" is left to the Sovereign States.

Need I remind you that we are a nation of laws, not a nation of federal fiats?

Education is standardized so kids can move from state to state, school to school, system to system, high schoo to technical school or college and be on the same general level as the other students.

This has nothing to do with ruling by...

Constantly improve toward what? The curve for improvement is likely asymptotic and after five to seven years will have been improved to the point of diminishing returns.

Next, I've studied the common core. If New York is following the common core, time must be allowed to refine some of the goals by building in transitions ... especially between grade levels. On many occasions, as I read the goals, I had to stop, look back, and ponder how they'd get from the last goal stated in the previous grade to the starting goals in the following grade. It's valuable but needs refining.

Last, assemble a committee of experienced classroom teachers and experienced administrators. Fund them with half a million dollars and send them to Germany to video record and study their apprenticeship programs and technical colleges. Then implement something similar in NYC. So long as the education is kept linked with academic studies so the students can later take college courses if desired, this won't diminish anyone's future.

By age 16 most students can identify whether they want to follow an academic college prep program or begin a serious technical-career program.

If it's a high-level program such as used in Germany, it won't become a dumping ground ... and it can be held to the same improvement standards as any other education institution. The focus is to get students to the point where they value and see as relevant education from age 16 to 18 rather than seeing it as a waste of time.
